This game can give you some of the most fun and dynamic fights I've ever seen in my life. Once you start getting the hang of it, you can burn hours and hours just fighting nonstop. Every weapon handles a little bit differently, there's a ton of small tricks to pull off, and fights can be decided in a split second mouse twitch, intense stuff. 

As an example, I had a fight against an enemy using a voulge while I had a longsword. He managed to catch my leg while I was advancing, but I managed to stick my sword into his leg(by half swording after I closed the distance). We both fell, but I got up first. Without a weapon, the only option I had was to grab the bastard and punch him repeatedly as we both tumbled once again. I got up, took his voulge as he unsheathed his backup sword. The motion to unsheathe was too much for his leg(that still had the longsword stuck to it) so he stumbled backwards a final time before I sliced him open with his own weapon. It happens dynamically and swiftly, there's no awkward delay as you switch weapons or stances.

Of course, there's also matches that end instantly, with me parrying an initial swing and slicing my enemy's neck open between his armor plates. Beautiful stuff, the possibility of becoming extremely precise and deadly keeps you going.

If you're easily frustrated though, I recommend not playing the challenge mode. Stick to free play(for technical play) or the Abyss(for laughs), because the physics engine is not perfect and will lead to a lot of very unfair deaths. Sometimes, weapons will clip into you after you parry them, meaning your organs explode. One light shoulder tap will sometimes just instakill you for no reason. Bosses are designed to be as unfair(extra health, extra size, better armor) as possible. Stepping on an axe will launch it into your crotch and bisect you, somehow. 

Stuff like that just gets you a "ah, snap" or a laugh when it happens in a free mode duel, but when you're deep in the challenge mode and die to a physics glitch, it just sucks.

There's also a bit of awkwardness regarding your character taking too long to get up after falling, some swings being oddly weak, just a result of the physics engine doing most of the heavy lifting in combat. It's hard to judge whether those aspects are working or not because it's still in development, but it's a hell of a lot of fun.

I think this game is exactly the kind of medieval combat sandbox I've always wanted but never really found! The NPC AI is fun to experiment on, and the weapons are vast and varied. I think the game could also be a little better optimized for lower-end PCs, ideally without making the game as unplayably difficult to look at as it is on its lowest graphics settings. The addition of the Abyss, while a welcome addition from the Playtest, also causes issues on lower-end PCs, just like its Playtest counterpart. Whenever I load into Abyss mode, my game crashes immediately, which is rather problematic in tournament mode specifically, since Abyss is now used as a sort of "sink-or-swim" minigame in order not to lose rank progress. I find myself wishing I could just toggle it off.

In the end though, I've had a lot of fun playing this game, and I only hope that in the future, I will still be able to play the final release on my average old laptop! This game can give you some of the most fun and dynamic fights I've ever seen in my life. Once you start getting the hang of it, you can burn hours and hours just fighting nonstop. Every weapon handles a little bit differently, there's a ton of small tricks to pull off, and fights can be decided in a split second mouse twitch, intense stuff. 

As an example, I had a fight against an enemy using a voulge while I had a longsword. He managed to catch my leg while I was advancing, but I managed to stick my sword into his leg(by half swording after I closed the distance). We both fell, but I got up first. Without a weapon, the only option I had was to grab the bastard and punch him repeatedly as we both tumbled once again. I got up, took his voulge as he unsheathed his backup sword. The motion to unsheathe was too much for his leg(that still had the longsword stuck to it) so he stumbled backwards a final time before I sliced him open with his own weapon. It happens dynamically and swiftly, there's no awkward delay as you switch weapons or stances.

Of course, there's also matches that end instantly, with me parrying an initial swing and slicing my enemy's neck open between his armor plates. Beautiful stuff, the possibility of becoming extremely precise and deadly keeps you going.

If you're easily frustrated though, I recommend not playing the challenge mode. Stick to free play(for technical play) or the Abyss(for laughs), because the physics engine is not perfect and will lead to a lot of very unfair deaths. Sometimes, weapons will clip into you after you parry them, meaning your organs explode. One light shoulder tap will sometimes just instakill you for no reason. Bosses are designed to be as unfair(extra health, extra size, better armor) as possible. Stepping on an axe will launch it into your crotch and bisect you, somehow. 

Stuff like that just gets you a "ah, snap" or a laugh when it happens in a free mode duel, but when you're deep in the challenge mode and die to a physics glitch, it just sucks.

There's also a bit of awkwardness regarding your character taking too long to get up after falling, some swings being oddly weak, just a result of the physics engine doing most of the heavy lifting in combat. It's hard to judge whether those aspects are working or not because it's still in development, but it's a hell of a lot of fun.

Another thing worth mentioning is that the keyboard input response is abysmal. I prefer not to play with the shield, so I tend to drop it before battle. Although I have put a significant amount of time into this game, and I truly enjoy a lot of the fighting elements of the game, I cannot in good faith recommend this game due to the god-awful character models and buggy input response.

Especially in Gauntlet Mode, you can do everything right and still randomly fall over and lose all of your progress. The amount of times I ragequit this game, not due to lack of skill but due to gameplay failure beyond my control is hard to quantify.

Another thing worth mentioning is that the keyboard input response is abysmal. I prefer not to play with the shield, so I tend to drop it before battle. There have been times where I have mashed the Q key over 20 times and my character will still be holding their shield when I go to take a swing with my sword. There have been times where I have stood directly over a weapon in Spoilance, pressed the E key to pick it up, and my character will crouch down, reach out for the weapon and grab nothing. There have been times where I have been running and my character suddenly stops moving because the WASD key input randomly stops responding.

The give-up/respawn timer is also extremely slow. The only way to save your progress in Gauntlet Mode when you fall over due to some inexplicable physics error is to give up immediately, but the timer to give up takes approximately 3-5 business days to finish, and in that time you're being attacked and killed nonstop with no recourse whatsoever. You might as well just delete the game because that's 90% of the gameplay experience.

The fighting mechanic and the weapons selection in this game are very good. The physics and the gore aspect of the game are excellent and I commend the developers for the true dedication and detail that they seem to have put into this game. But until the fundamental gameplay issues are corrected, I will not post a positive review for this game.

my most egregious issue with the game though primarily lies in the ultimate challenge. firstly, while i may be incorrect on this, the fact you cannot access this natively in free mode - despite it being /free/ mode where you would imagine everything would be accessible alongside the fact it was added due to pushback from the playerbase due to dissatisfaction with the most recent version - almost feels like it's forcing players into playing gauntlet mode just so they can unlock this wherein many players already simply do not want to. even besides this, having completed the main gauntlet, i have experienced (in every run where i have not had to back out of it due to poor RNG in terms of what weapons are dropped to me) a fatal unity error that simply prevents me from progressing to the end as it will just force-close the game. this kind of issue, ESPECIALLY in a mode where it's intended to be one life, having a decent attempt at the ultimate challenge being nullified because of the game rather than any fault on your part is nothing short of infuriating. i would have expected an error such as this to be caught in playtesting, considering how drastic it is and how frequently it seems to be occuring, but i digress. 

i just really cannot recommend this game in its current state. i am aware it is a demo, but i generally see this most recent update as a downgrade to the previous version of the demo. abyss mode ceases to be enjoyable, i still don't understand why there is no equipment selector (especially in free mode), and the ultimate challenge consistently causing crashes fails to make it a worthy successor to what abyss mode could have been
